title: What liability does a beneficiary have compared to the executor of a probate estate that has been closed?
question: If any unforeseen debts (from third parties, credit cards or what not) or debt collections from the IRS come due after the probate has been closed who are the responsible parties assuming only two beneficiaries who split estate 50/50 and one was executor? What is the Executor vs regular beneficiary liability on those debts? And is there any limitations on how long after they can put in a claim?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Estates,Taxes and estate planning,Executor of will,Probate,Trust beneficiaries,Tax law
answers: Generally speaking, a creditor if an estate has four months within which to file a claim against the estate. Beyond this, there is a strict one year statute of limitations regarding a creditor's ability to bring claim against a decedent's estate for claims that arose before the death of the decedent. The IRS is an exception to these rules. If an executor distributed assets of the estate without paying a creditor, the executor may held personally liable. What's more, anyone who inherits from a decedent is liable up to the amount inherited for unpaid debts of the decedent (subject to the rules governing the ability of a creditor to enforce a claim).

The first question is whether or not the collecting party waited too long to make their demand for payment. *Generally* speaking, a creditor has four months from the issuance of Letters Testamentary, and the IRS has three years from the date the last return was filed. However, there are other factors that can change this - you should speak with an attorney about the particulars of your case.

That said, the executor is generally personally liable for the debts, BUT may be able to sue the beneficiary for indemnification (reimbursement) for their share of the collected property. You need to speak to a lawyer.
Any unforeseen debts should be paid from the estate and if done properly, there should be reserve available to pay for this. The executor is the one who holds the liability.
